It belongs to the family Rhamnaceae and is characterized by its dense, velvety foliage that gives it its common name. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, followed by small, round fruits that are typically reddish when mature. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates and is often found in moist, well-drained soils. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and natural habitats.
